characters: EXT. BUS PASSING THROUGH SMALL TOWN NIGHT
INT. BOB AND DIANNE'S BEDROOM DAY
INT. RICK AND NADINE'S BEDROOM DAY

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR DAY
dialogues.text: An OVERHEAD VIEW of BOB HUGHES lying down in the back sea of a 1968 Cadillac. He is looking up at the ceiling of the car, at the camera, and his features are changing thi way and that, sometimes eeking out a giggle or an inspire laugh, looking like some sort of wired druq addict with thoughts racing by too fast to interpret by his features.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I figured I was qualified to write a book, if I could ever sit down long enough in one place to do it. It would be titled, A Dope Fiend's Guide to Drug Stores, or something like that. CLOSE VIEW of Bob's face and shifting eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And in it the curious reader would find flights of fancy, gems of creativity, artistry, and yes even honest-to-goodness poetry. Of course it would have a lot of the standard stuff, like picking locks... EXT. PHARMACY #1 ROOFTOP NIGHT ae Bob sawing a hole in the roof of a closed pharmacy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: + » .0r sawing holes in roofs. Yeah, sawing holes, I liked to do that. When working away with hand drills and saws and such, I even thought of myself as a half-assed carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE VIEW of Bob's face in the back seat of the Cadillac HE CRACKS a smile and winks absentmindedly. INT. PHARMACY #1 NIGHT ak Bob finding all sorts of prescription drugs behind the counter of a closed pharmacy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think we'll give it the old beaver shot this time. Up in the front seat, his partners know he isn't expectin a response. There's DIANNE, NADINE AND RICK, and all are used to Bob being in his own little world there. (Allow time for voice over history of each character, like: there was Dianne. She wouldn't tell a cop shit even if she had a mouthful.) EXT. PORTLAND OREGON CITY STREET DAY ae EXT, PORTLAND OREGON itt ones The car pulls over to a curb and pushes other cars away making room for their getaway. Bob gets out first and casually walks down the sidewalk as if window shopping. An OLD WOMAN walking her POODLE approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nice day, huh? Then Bob smiles at the OLD WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PENITENTIARY DAY
dialogues.text: Long shot of Bob walking down hallway with guard. JAIL BARS slide open in front of Bob. He is smiling that same SMILE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DAY
dialogues.text: Bob walks through glass doors into a PHARMACY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE VIEW of Rx sign, Bob steps neatly past the checkout counter and takes a look at veterinary supplies ona shelf. DIANNE enters the Pharmacy. - THE NEXT PERSON to enter the Pharmacy is NADINE, not long out of her teens, her blouse is scanty and her skirt stop well above the knees.  9-10-88 3. THE FOURTH MEMBER of the group enters, RICK, the muscle. Nadine proceeds down the store's main aisle and stops at the perfume counter. Rick takes a post near the entrance pretending to look through the get well cards. Dianne is engaged in an over the counter conversation wit the DRUGGIST. She has a pack of gum in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Do you have Wintogreen gum? Why don't you have wintogreen gum?

dialogues.speaker: DRUGGIST
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, I don't believe that we carry it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Could you order it?

dialogues.speaker: DRUGGIST
dialogues.text: Ma'am? Bob gives the signal to Dianne who is peering over her sunglasses, then scratches her rear, signaling Nadine who goes into her act.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Help! This lady is having a seizure. She might swallow her tongue! Nadine SCREAMS and falls backward against a low display case, leaving her body arched to make the most of the fac that she's wearing a very short skirt. She begins to convulse and jerk, trying to mimic the symptoms of an epileptic seizure. VIEW of the Druggist's eyes, and they are taking special notice of Nadine's torso; he bounds over the counter to Nadine's rescue. Bob makes his move, quickly ducking behind the vacated counter and dropping to his knees. MOVING VIEW of Bob scooting along, looking for any drawer or cabinet with a lock. Midway along the counter he finds what he is looking for. He spies a drawer and opens it. Dianne, spying a checkout girl on her way to the action, COUGHS a signal to Bob to hurry up. Bob responds to Dianne's cough and scurries back down to the end of the counter and peeks around to see if things are safe.  10 9-10-88 BOB'S VIEW. The checkout girl is helping the druggist with Nadine. Bob is satisfied that it is safe, and scurries back to th drawer. He straightens up to his knees and begins rifling the contents. The sweat is standing up on his forehead. His hands start to shake and his knees quiver and jerk as he scoots back down the aisle around the pill shelves and into the back room. Dianne begins to start another COUGHING FIT as the druggist is on his way back behind the counter going to the phone. Bob tries the back door but it is locked. Now the druggist is in Bob's sight and he has to operate on the back door to the druggist's back. Bob quietly pulls out a screwdriver and smoothly takes th locked door off the hinges, very quietly, and leaves the back room.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: (to the counter girl) Excuse me...are you too busy to take this money for some cough syrup? The counter girl, holding Nadine, looks at Dianne like sh is crazy and Dianne smiles for the benefit of all the SURROUNDING CUSTOMERS, and quietly leaves. VIEW of Nadine arched over the low display, and hearing a distant AMBULANCE SIREN, she sits up, rearranges her clothing and hair, tries to look embarrassed, deftly disengages the hands of the counter girl holding her, and walks out the door. She is followed by Rick. The druggist and the checkout girl stand in amazement as they leave. We see the druggist's has a nagging suspicion that they have been HAD.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DAY
dialogues.text: Dianne leans into backseat window to kiss Bob and then enters the driver's side of the Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is in the back seat lying down.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: How'd we do?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So, 80...  11 12 9-10-88 Dianne starts the engine and nervously taps the steering wheel with her long tapered fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I wish they'd get a move on, I've told them and told them to get the hell out once we've made our goddamn move. Fuck me blue! Bob raises up enough to look out the back window.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: For Christsakes, Dianne, watch your language. Who in the hell do you think you are, Ma Barker or somebody?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Just who in the fuck do you think you are, my father? If you can cuss, so can I goddamnit! Bob sits up and keeps looking out the rear window, and spots Rick and Nadine casually strolling down the sidewalk, hand in hand, toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob opens the door of the car and calls out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, I said walk not crawl. Rick and Nadine take their places in the car next to Dianne.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: You said walk and that's what we done, walk, can't we do nothin' right?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, I said walk, but I didn't mean you had to window shop all along the way. Rick grins. Dianne pulls out of the parking place.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Anybody got an outfit up there? Dianne turns completely around, disregarding traffic.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Bob, why do you have to fix in the car? Can't you wait until we get home like everybody else?  9-10-88

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Shut up and watch your driving. Bob sits up a bit and looks out the window of the car, like a little kid with his nose pressed against the glass

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: After any kind of drug haul, everyone in the crew indulged to the utmost. I laughed to myself as I pictured blues or dilaudid in such great amounts that the spoon would literally be overflowing. Upon entering my vein the drug would start a warm itch that would surge along until the brain consumed it in a gentle explosion that began in the back of the neck and rose rapidly, until I felt such pleasure that the whole world sympathized and took ona soft, lofty appeal. Everything was grand then. Your worst enemy, he wasn't so bad. The ants in the grass, they were just doing their thing. Everything took on the rosy hue of unlimited success, you could do no wrong. As long as it lasted, life was beautiful. Dianne has been riding in the front seat swearing at the traffic quite liberally, and a few choice four letter words drift into Bob's quiet musings in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (to Dianne) Boy what a bitchy group! Fuck this, and screw that, Dianne, what kind of an example are you setting for the youngsters anyway? Dianne takes her eyes off the road, turning to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: You're goddamn lucky that I have to keep my eyes on the road. . .

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes on the road then.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: .» . .and the steering wheel in my hand because otherwise you would be a good candidate for strangling.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well it don't look like you are doing that great a job of keeping your eyes on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac drifts effortlessly through a red light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT DAY
dialogues.text: The car slows to a halt in front of the JOSEPHINE APARTMENTS. Bob can be seen peeking out the back window of the car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR DAY
dialogues.text: Bob turns around to see the rest of the crew.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Now, everybody. Just act cool. It's like we've just come back from church. This being Sunday morning, we should make it believable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car jumps excitedly over a bumpy drive and squeals it's tires a little as it makes its way to the back of th apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: For some reason, every dope fiend in the area could tell if you were holding. Across the street, DAVID, a long haired hippy about twenty-one years old, sits up in an easy chair on the porch of his house, as if he just woke up.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The hangers on, the rip-off artists, that is. Not the cops. They couldn't smell a dead rat two feet away. But the damn dope fiend snitches could. At this point David does look a little like he is sniffin the air as he puts on a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It didn't make any difference how careful you were. They could sense it. They could almost smell it. David makes his way down the steps of his porch and sees: Bob, Nadine, Rick and Dianne skipping from the car quickl into their apartment.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They could tell by the way you drove in the yard, by the way you hurried into the  15 9-10-88

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (continued) apartment, and if you made a studied, careful approach, they could sense it even more. There was just no way to improvise that disgusted sick feeling of coming home with nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four sitting around a coffee table that has fast food take-out soft drink cups on it. Bob is fishing out the drugs.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Give me a blue.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nadine?

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Give me the same, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (smiles) No, I don't think so, Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Why not? Dianne brings her head up and looks right through Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Nadine, you can't shoot no goddamn blue. Give her half of one, Bob, that'll keep her in the crapper all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: (fighting back) Goddamnit, I was in there just like you, I ought to get the same as everyone else, even if I can't shoot it all right now. I could save it, or maybe sell it and get me a few things.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, Nadine, I'l] tell you, that just ain't the way things work around here. You don't do shit. All you've done is shag your twat, and that ain't nothin'. It's me that's taking the big risk. What are they going to bust you for, having a fit in a drug store?  9-10-88 9.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. APARTMENT DAY
dialogues.text: cr David is walking across the lawn toward the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Well, how about Dianne, she ain't done nothing either?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Don't give her a damn thing. Kick her ass out in the street where we found her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, no fair is fair, you want your fourth, you got it, Nadine. But I ain't taking on no apprentices and giving them a full end of my thing. You take it and get out. At this , Nadine looks confused, like she doesn't know what she wants.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Goddamn you, Nadine! Take your half a blue and shut up, shoot it and go puke awhile. A KNOCK sounds on the door. Quickly Dianne scoops up all the bottles and runs for the ~~ bedroom. Bob draws a forty-five automatic pistol from under the couch cushion. Holding it at arms length pointed at the floor, he approaches the door's peephole. VIEW through the peephole. Bob recognizes the intruder.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What do you want, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I just want to see you for a minute, Bob, let me in.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You alone?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hell yes, I'm alone, what'd you think, I brought my rat-faced granny along to hold my hand? Nadine and Rick are standing as if glued to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You, Nadine, pick up those spoons, outfits and Cr that glass of water. Rick you get your goddamn gun out and get in the bedroom and back me up.  9-10-88 10. Both Rick and Nadine jump at his order. Bob opens the door and points his cocked gun at the long-haired disheveled young man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What the hell, pard, you finally gone completely crazy or something? David smiles at the ritual. He slowly steps into the apartment and looks over Bob's shoulder to see Rick's arm and gun protruding around the door jam of the bedroom. Then he carefully takes off his jacket, swirls around lik a ballet dancer doing a swan number and relaxes on the couch in a half sitting and half lying position.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you holding, pard?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I ain't holding shit, David. Bob lowers his gun and tries his best to look innocent.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I was just thinking of dropping by your place to see if you've got any speed. David smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I got some speed. David laughs, embarrassed somewhat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What kind of speed you got?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Methadrine crystal.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (grins) You know what, David? You could have little balls of shit wrapped up in those little cellophane bags of yours and your answer would always be the same, methadrine crystal.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, Bob, really, this is good stuff, clears right up in the spoon, no residue, hair-raising flash, here, you try one on the house.  16 9-10-88 il. Bob is skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay, how much you got on you right now?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ten grams. Bob looks to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay, just a moment, I got to talk to Dianne first. INT. BEDROOM DAY xe Bob enters and finds Dianne straddling the window sill, still clutching her armload of small bottles. She has heard everything in the next room and shows dissatisfaction with the way things are turning out. Bob grins at her sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How about some speed, baby? The man says that he's got methedrine crystal.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What do you want that goddamn speed for? You know how ringy it makes you. It turns you into a different person, Bob, and I don't much like that person. Bob holds out his hands, palms up in the age old gesture, as if to say, "Oh, what the hell, one more time isn't going to hurt anything." And Bob's voice takes on the excitement of a small boy in a candy shop.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Baby, listen to me, what night is this anyway? It's Sunday, right? How about us getting some speed, see, and then we'll all jump in the car and get that big fat pharmacy. You know how these things go. When you're hot, you shoot the works, when you're cold, you lay off a bit. Well right now I'm hot, baby, I'm so hot I'm burning all over.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Alright, buster, 1£ you're so goddamn hot why don't you lay me down on the bed and make love to me right now? Bob turns away in disgust.  17 18 19 9-10-88 12.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh crap, you know what I mean, Dianne. I'm hot to steal. We can do that any goddamn time. Bob moves away quickly and slams the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: For Christ-sakes, you got to bring up crap like that at a time like this? Bob looks around as if trying to spot the answer to his problems.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT LIVING ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Rick is still holding the gun, but not pointing it at David, they are all listening to Bob and Dianne's conversation,

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So, okay, I ain't been doing so good in that department. What do you want me to do? I'm hooked baby, I'm not like a woman. I got to be the one that gets it up first . All you do is think about sex, you pervert. Dianne draws her outside leg back over the window sill into the room.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Hell, how much goddamn speed you going to get off that creep? Be sure to get enough for all of us. And don't you ever call me a pervert again or I'l] cut your fucking heart out! Bob relaxes and grins.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I know you will, baby, I know you will. INT. LIVING ROOM DAY ek Bob enters.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You got any blues?  9-10-88 13.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (looks perplexed) Hell no, I ain't got no blues! You know how hard it is to pick up blues these days?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How about dilaudid, you got any sixteenths?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (eyebrows go up again) Hell no, if I had sixteenths, you think I'd be sitting here rapping to you about some shitty speed? Now how about some morphine. I got some good old morphine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What'd you get, man, morphine sulfate, quarters or halves?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, man, (lapsing into black jargon) I got quarters and halves. It's got a little atrophine in it, but. Just take you a little old ink blotter, lay the tablets out on them in rows, place one drop of water on each one and the atrophine eases right off into the blotter and you're home free. Throw the little fellers off in the spoon and you're raring to go.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You're crazy, man, I can't even read a stop sign when I'm on that crap, my eyes go so far out of focus. I ain't trading no uptown crank for no downtown trash.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well you know how it is these days, David. That's all I got and all I can give.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bullshit, bullshit, bullshit, if you didn't have nothin' more you wouldn't be even trading off that. You think I'm dumb, man, but I'm not as dumb as you think.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (shrugs) What can I say. David fusses and fumes and heads for the door. Bob just grins at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Too bad we couldn't do business, pard.  9-10-88 14. At the last second David turns from the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, man, how many quarter grains of morphine you going to give me for that?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll hit you with nine quarters per package, and that's just because I'm feeling good and because you're a real standup dude. I'll even throw in an ink blotter. How's that? I'll] take all ten quarters from you. Dianne comes from the bedroom and leans against the door jam.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You want ten, so okay, you get ten. That's nine apiece, nine times, ten, let's see, that's. ..

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: That's ninety, Bob. If looks could kill, Nadine is dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right. Ninety. Dianne gives them all a look of complete disgust and head for the bedroom to get the pills. David sneaks a glance at Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How much you want for her, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How much you want for her, man, the female, the fox. Bob turns his pistol on Nadine while he addresses David.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know what, sport? I'd kill that girl right here before I'd sell her to you. What'd you think I'm some kind of closet pimp? I never heard of such a violation of the right of womanhood in all my life.  9-10-88 15. David doesn't know how to react, so he just nods affirmatively to Bob's question.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Out of curiosity, how many bags of speed would you give for her? David slumped with relief and headed toward Nadine with his hand extended, ready to feel for himself if all the curves were real.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: You little twirp. You come one step closer to me and I'll knock your block off. David hesitates, draws his hand to his side and turns to catch Bob's reaction. Dianne saves the situation by throwing the pills on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Pick up your stuff and go. We got some things to do. David picks up his stuff and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I like her. I might come back sometime and see you about trading for her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Alright, twirpy. You do that. Rick bolts the door behind David. Bob throws his gun on the couch on his way to examine the goods. Nadine is indignant.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: I ain't going to be sold like no pig in the poke to nobody. Bob looks up from the speed he is inspecting.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The next time you come to my aid and help me with my arithmatic when it's unfavorable to us, I'll drag you out and sell you to the first one-eyed Philippino I can find, for whatever he'll goddamn give me. Even if it's only a pack of chewing gum. Nadine turns away and goes outside. Rick goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don't give her no heavy, Rick. We've got work to do tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIEUTENANT GENTRY, TROUSINSKI, and a handful of other police are investigating Bob's work. OUR VIEW moves in close on Gentry's FACE. (Perhaps he picks up a rabbit's foot off the floor or is chewing on a golf tee.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Nadine are talking.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Listen, Nadine. Bob's one of the best people you'll ever run across in your entire life.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: He asked that twirp how much he'd give for me.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He wasn't going to sell you to that stimg, he was just trying to teach you a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: I'm worth a whole lot more than a pack of chewing gum, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: If David had laid a hand on you, he would have regretted it, I can tell you that. Man do you know what Bob would do for you, or me or Dianne or anyone in his crew? He'd literally die for you, Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: I just can't imagine Bob Hughes dying for me, why is that Rick?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't believe me, but I know it's true. Why do you think he always dives, or is always the first one in with the gun? The only reason he always tries to act so mean is because he's so soft that he's afraid you and everyone else will find out and take advantage of him. Man I've been hearing about Bob for years. He's notorious for that one particular thing, along with a lot more obvious talents. Don't let him or Dianne get you down. They mean well.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: I just hope you're right, baby. I just hope you'tre right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see through the window into Rick and Nadine's room as they are talking. We pedestal down and see Dianne digging a hole where she places the drugs. OMIT ae INT. LIVING ROOM NIGHT xe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob isn't about to give in yet. He hides his gun inside a golf bag which is sitting in the corner of the room. Dianne stands up and wrestles Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing? The goddamn bitch has gone completely crazy. What do you want to go to bed for? Man, we ought to be out working. Dianne begins to undress Bob, and herself.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I know this hospital on the coast, I just know is a virgin. I know it is.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: You're crazy Bob, you know that? You ain't fucked me in a month and you're crazier than a shithouse rat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I mean this place has got security zero.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: We just pulled off the best score we've made in months and off you trot looking for more.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll bet they got blow, mammy, all those hospitals hold big time coke.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: why don't you let me dive next time? I'm as good as you and you know it. I've even heard you tell people that I'm better than you are. I'm sick of standing around coughing and driving the car and not getting fucked.  30 31 9-10-88 18.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Babe...

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: You know me, honey, I can't stand to go on forever like this. Why don't you roll over and lay down on the bed and just hold me for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hold you? What do you want me to hold you for? Man we ought to get cracking, get in the car and see if we can't make it up to that hospital before it gets daylight out. Boy you'll love this one, Dianne. I'11 even let you hacksaw some on the bars.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, boy, you'll let me hacksaw on the bars. Whoopee. For Christsakes, you mean you're not even going to let me go inside? I thought you loved me. You won't fuck me and you won't let me go inside. Bob and Dianne begin to mess around.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Let's go on up the coast right now and just look over this hospital 1f nothing else. I mean, you'll just cream your jeans when you see it. It sits way back in the woods. It's a giveaway, baby. I can actually see those big gallon jugs of pills on the shelves. Thousands of them, baby, thousands of them. Coke by the twenty ounce jug! Can you imagine twenty ounces of coke? Did I ever tell you about the time we got the hospital over east of the mountains and got the twenty ounce jug of coke?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: (repeats Bob's last line along with him) Only about ten thousand times. Dianne body freezes a the SOUND of the front door RIPPING away from its hinges, and crashing to the apartment floor FOUR BURLY NARCOTICS DETECTIVES COME galloping across the downed door like a bunch of mustangs breaking out of a corral. Guns drawn, faces tight, muscles coiled, they pair off into two teams, two grab Bob and Dianne, and the other two knock the door down to Rick and Nadine's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 32 33 9-10-88 19. INT. RICK AND NADINE'S BEDROOM NIGHT ae

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Nadine are also against the wall as the officers look through that part of the apartment. INT. BEDROOM NIGHT aK

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Alright you two, you turn around. Dianne and Bob comply.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Getting a little droopy there in the tits, aren't we, Dianne? By now Dianne is relaxed into it. She looks at her breasts, smiles and says:

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's goddamn Bob's fault. He won't take them out for exercise anymore. Gentry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Bob, you been shooting too much dope again? Seems like the last time we were by here and you were hooked to the gills, Dianne was complaining of the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, you know how it is, out on the job all day. Work, work, work like a dog, man comes home, he wants to relax a bit

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I've been hearing about all that work you've been doing. We were saying the other day, looks like old Bob Hughes has finally slowed down a bit. And then Wham-bam, you knock off another pharmacy. Didn't you sort of expect us to drop by?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute, that wasn't me, pal. I ain't hit no poison shop in years, look at.me. Do I look like I'm using. He does.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Looks like you're hooked to the gills.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You got a warrant, pal?  9-10-88 20.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got a warrant, Bob. We put it ona micro dot. I got it pasted right on the end of a thirty eight slug. You want to see it Bob? I'll shoot it through, if you'll just turn your eves backwards, you can read it when it passes Y.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wow, man, you guys are heavy, what you been reading, Mickey Spillane?

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: You know what they give little punks like you for holking illegal class A narcotics?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What can I say? I'm not holding. Let me call my attorney. I'm sure he can straighten all this out in a few minutes. Two other DETECTIVES, Halamer and Trousinski, begin to trash the apartment. They reach the Golf clubs in the corner and Bob shakes Trousinski dump them out on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey Gentry, what are you shooting these days? I got my handicap down pretty good near eight, how about that? his head yes and looks at Gentry.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Eight huh?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Shot three eagles on the back side alone last time I played Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I don't play those public courses, greaseball, that course is for pussies, no wonder you have an eight handicap.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey, how am I supposed to play if my clubs are all broke? is now breaking them in half. The sympathy play is working on Gentry.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Alright, Trousinski, break two more then leave the clubs alone.  34 35 9-10-86§ 21. Gentry pauses.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: You haven't gone out in the bushes and buried the drugs again, have you Dianne?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about. Why don't you just go piss up a rope, fuckwad.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Dianne, what language you use. Gentry looks to his partner and chuckles. Bob smiles smile.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I always heard you guys had class.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I tried to talk to her about her language but she still talks like a truck driver.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Okay, kiddies, here's how it's coming down. You can just tell us where it's at and save yourselves a whole lot of trouble or you can sit there with your mouths shut while we tear this apartment apart board by board. Now how's it going to be? his "What-can-I-say-it's-out-of-my-hands"

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Tear away. This place is rented and insured and my lawyer will no doubt file against you, because, pard, you ain't findin' nothing in this apartment unless you brought it with you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: The agents bring in fire axes, they rip clothing. They rip the cushions off the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dismantling the stove, hacking furniture. Emptying the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clothing ripped to little bits, linings of jackets torn out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Unscrewing heating duct.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HEATING DUCT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Flashlights searching.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hacking furniture with axes. DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light is streaming in the windows. Huddled in a corner of the living room, the agents gone, are Rick, Nadine, Diann and Bob. Some are showing twitchiness of withdrawal.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You going to sue them, Bob? I'd sue the hell out of them if it was up to me. Bob, who's head is buried in his arms that are gathered around his legs, lifts his head up and yawns.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No. Sue them? Hell no, I ain't going to sue them. I told you all this crap was rented and insured. What do I want to sue them for?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How about our clothes?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Them rags? Fuck them rags, we can always go out and shoplift some more. Shit, I love them cops. Bob thought for a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dianne, call your stupid sister and have her bring us enough clothes to go around.  9-10-88 23.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Why do I have to go to the phone like I am? And just why does my sister have to be stupid?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: All right, go call your smart sister.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I'll go make the goddamn call, but you either got to fuck me when I get back, or you got to let me go in that hospital pharmacy with you when we hit it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: OK, I'm an easy rider. 39 INT. APARTMENT DAY ek Dianne's smart SISTER looks around the room in amazement. She touches parts of the wreckage.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Good God, what did they use, sledge hammers?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: No, fireaxes.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Christ I've seen tornadoes down south that didn't produce this kind of destruction. .Dianne's sister never really looks Bob in the eye, even when she is talking to him she is wandering around the room looking at some of the damage or looking at Dianne.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I was just reading about tornadoes in the encyclopedia. It's very scientific, I think, and they were saying that they do a lot of damage but they rarely hit the inside of an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: By the way Bob, what happened to your prick? It looks like it's pointing to China permanently. Have you been doing too much speed, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (laughs it off)

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Oh boy, Bob, you're really on top of it all today. Why don't you just leave Dianne, Bob,  40 9-10-88 24.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: (continued) and go join one of those female impersonator clubs. And then no doubt you'd be happy, to have finally found your place in life, contributing to a normal segment of our community. Bob blows up at her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Get her out of here, Dianne, get her out! And with that Bob hurriedly strides to the bathroom to ge out of range of the barrage of insults he knows are forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: That's what I always liked about old Bob. He just won't stand around to lose. He'll run every time, the yellow-bellied sonofabitch. She drops the clothing on the littered floor and heads fo the door.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Dianne, and be sure to call your other sister next time. I've done my good deed for the month. Dianne looks up from a needle and a spoon she is using to fix with. Pull back from this image as Dianne feels the drugs.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks, smarty, sorry I couldn't be more sociable, but what can one do when one doesn't even have a chair to offer? EXT. APARTMENT DAY (later) Bob hands Rick the keys to the car. Everyone is dressed in clothes that don't really fit them, in style at least. Bob has a duck-hunting jacket on with a duck sewn on to the back of it, and Dianne is wearing a bowling shirt. Rick and Nadine are dressed like a very conservative suburban couple.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You two take the car and go look for an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: OK Bob, I will.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don't fuck it up.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I won't Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Get one over on the west side. We haven't hit nothing there in weeks, so things ought to be cool over there.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'll get a real comfortable place.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay. Don't get an uncomfortable place...Dianne and I will go over to my mom's in a taxi and get some clothes I left there, okay? INT. CAR DAY ak View of the window of the car, Rick driving, Nadine in th frame, looking out over the city passing by out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very skinny man shows Nadine and Rick an apartment. Rick looks out the window like someone may have followed them there.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: We gotta get some shades for these windows, maybe some sheets. The man doesn't pay attention. He is listing off the terms.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY MAN
dialogues.text: Deposit of 150. Key charge is 10 dollars... (pause) any children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne winces as the door swings open and Bob's MOTHER gasps, throwing her hand to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hi, mom, how're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: 41B
dialogues.text: 9-10-88 26. Bob hugs his mom.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, it's my dope fiend thieving son and his crazy nymphomaniac wife. Mom closes the door and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's Mom makes her way through a cozy house, a bird ina cage, a television that is on. She stops at a window that is open and Bob is on the other side of it.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Please tell me what I did to deserve this. Never knowing when there's going to be a knock on the door and someone telling me my baby's dead. ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom shuts the window on Bob and Dianne. They make their way around the house. OTHER NEIGHBORS are looking on now. Bob and Dianne meet Mom at the back door.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: » + » green with an overdose, shot by a mad pharmacist or run down by a car fleeing from police pursuit. . . why me?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mom, do you by chance still have those clothes I left here when we got sent to the joint last time?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: No, I gave all that stuff away years ago. I thought you were never going to get out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: But Mom, how could you think that. ..

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: The first time he got arrested he was a little boy, I went down to the police department, along with that horrible Tom the Priest who turned out to be his pusher, and the cops said they'd let him go if he'd just tell who the rest of his pals were. He told me right to my face, "I can't Mom, them's my friends."  4ic

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (continued) Some friends. They left him. He is a thief and a dope fiend and that is more important to him than I am. He can go to prison. He likes it there anyway, don't you Robert?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (nods absent mindedly) If you say so, mom. Mrs Hughes groans in despair as Bob goes inside the house

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC DAY
dialogues.text: Bob finds clothes and a picture of his mom and dad when h was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I'd ask you to sit down, Dianne, but the last time I did that you fell asleep and dropped a burning cigarette on my couch and burned a hole in it. So if you please, just stand where you are so I can watch you, and catch you should you fall asleep standing on your feet. I wouldn't want you to burn yourself up or fall down and hurt yourself while you are in my home, Dianne.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Why do you hate Bob and I so, Mama? We never done anything to make you hate us so.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I don't hate you, Dianne, and I don't hate Robert either. And the good Lord knows that to be the truth. I truly feel pity for you both. You're grown up now, and yet you still act as children who want to do nothing but run and play. You cannot run and play all of your life, Dianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 9-10-88 28 Bob emerges with a suitcase filled with clothes draped across his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Is there anything else that belongs to you up there?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If there is, give it away. I can always get some more.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, to be sure, you'll just go out and steal some more.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, we gotta go, Mom. See you again soon. You be good now. And don't do anything I wouldn't do.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: And what could I possibly do that you are not capable of, I ask you that? Bob and Dianne walk to the end of the drive where the cab is still waiting for them and get in the car, Bob a littl depressed as he leaves his mother crying out her frustrations to the neighborhood. The neighbors are listening.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: What sins could I possibly do that you have not done a thousand times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Rick walk up the front path to the house.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey, Rick, nice work. This looks like a fucking comfortable place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick, Nadine and Bob are in the living room of their new apartment. Bob is turning on the television which is in the middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Do I have to go? You're not going to want a screamer or a shimmy girl on this one are you?  42a 9-10-88 29

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know. Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: They always got those signs around hospitals that says QUIET, and if I was to go into that shimmy act, they'd probably throw me into the psycho ward and I'd never get out. Bob fools with the television and thinks for a second. Dianne has

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, why the hell not. You just go ahead and stay here, Nadine. Just relax and watch a little TV. I can just see all those pretty colored bottles of pills that hospital is holding for me right now. Hot Dog!

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: (Her eyes light up) Oh, speaking of dogs, Bob, do you think Rick and I could get a dog, a little pup or something to hold and pet when you guys are gone?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nope, no dogs, and that's final.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What you got against dogs, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No fucking dogs! entered the living room.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Tell them what happened to the last one we had, Bob. Bob stops tuning the TV and sits down trying to forget th others are there.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If you want them to know, Dianne, you tell them.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Well, we had a dog once. . . his name was Panda, cutest little pup you ever did see. ..

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DAY
dialogues.text: VIEW of police car coming around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: 42D
dialogues.text: 9-10-88 30 VIEW of Bob and Dianne Slinking around their parked car and getting inside, but the DOG jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: So what happened was, the police were after us during a raid on a drugstore in the city, and little Panda got out of the car and ran away. VIEW of Dianne and Bob yelling for the dog.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We looked for him, but there was just no time. We had the heat on us and we had to get out of there. A POLICE CAR CRUISES BY Bob hiding on the other side of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob switches to another show and sits down to watch.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: ++ehell...

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: We were afraid the 1i1" dude was hit by a car, but no... .

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DAY
dialogues.text: The police have little Panda surrounded on the sidewalk. VIEW of the Police following him as he walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The police had him. And they followed him all the way home...

dialogues.speaker: INT. FLASHBACK APARTMENT DAY
dialogues.text: VIEW out the window of little Panda cruising up the sidewalk up to Bob and Dianne's apartment. The police are following him. Pull back the VIEW seeing Bob looking through the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: «.-he led them to us. He assisted in the arrest.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dog may be man's best friend but he really screwed me around I'll tell you that. On the TV, there is another show with a dog in it. And Bob gets right up and turns the TV off, losing his temper

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (shouting) It's off, we ain't going to the coast, we ain't going nowhere! Do you know what you have just done to us, Nadine, just by even mentioning dogs in our home?

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: No, I don't Bob, what did I do?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You just put a thirty-day hex on us, that's what. Right now our luck just flew out the window for thirty days. Have we got a calendar, so we'll know when the hex ends? What month is it anyway?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Jesus, Bob, nobody told us about not saying anything about dogs. How was we supposed to know? Bob pulls himself up into his most put-upon, abused manne and answers.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know why no one mentioned dogs? I'11 tell you why, because just to have mentioned them would have been a hex in itself.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Well, now that we're on the subject, is there any other sacred subjects or things we're not supposed to do that will affect our future?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact there are a few, and we might as well discuss them right now, being as how we are shut down for thirty days anyway. HATS. If I ever see a hat laying on a bed...you'll never see me again.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: That's a laugh.  Pause..

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Why a hat?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Because that's just the way it is, sweetie!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And mirrors. Don't ever look at the back side of a mirror, because when you do you'll affect your future because you're looking at yourself backwards. Actually, you are looking at your innerself and you don’t recognize it because you've never seen that side of yourself before. {Bob is getting confused at his own explanation) But anyway, you can freeze into motion your future that way and it can be either good or bad, in any case, we just don't want to take chances. Bob breathes for a second.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And there's cats. A lot of people are frightened of just black cats. As far as I'm concerned they're all bad. Have you ever noticed how they look at you sometimes, like they're superior to you? Well, that's because they are. They can readjust your future, especially if you sit on one, or in any way piss one off. So I just stay clear of the whole mess of them. Bob stops for a second again.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The main thing is just remember the hats. A goddamn hat is the king of them all. It's worth at least fifteen years bad luck or even death. I'd rather have death myself, because I just couldn't stand no fifteen year hex. Rick and Nadine remain silent mulling over Bob's latest erratic behavior. Dianne is shaking her head yes, and wholly agreeing with Bob's philosophy.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Relax, Bob, let's go lay down for awhile. You've been on the go for days. This thirty days ain't going to kill us now.  43 44a 44 45
33 INT. BEDROOM NIGHT ae

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne snuggles up next to Bob in bed. Bob has a golf club and mistakenly hits a bedroom lamp.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Don't let it get you down, Bob. Sometimes bad luck can be good luck. I mean look at all the times we either had a flat or engine trouble and made it to your score late, thinking it was good luck, you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hell, I can't even figure it all out myself. I just know from years of experience the things to dodge and the signs to look for, like, it is as if whoever manages such things is telling you, "Get out of there and get it, kid, it's there for the taking and everything's free this week. I'll let you know when your time is up. You'll see the signs. All you have to do is look for the signs."

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEIGHBORHOOD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Overhead view of small dog under porch light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small dog BARKS in the distance, a street light glisten off the dew on lawns of houses surrounding Bob's apartment. A dated model pickup with cab-over camper is parked across from the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentry draws back from field glasses that he is peering through. HALAMER, another detective speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: HALAMER
dialogues.text: Why don't we just go on up, plant some stuff on them and drag them on in? That usually works. Gentry blinks a couple of times to clear his vision and assumes a superior pose.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why, I don't want to get Hughes on no chickenshit possession beef, and that's all you're going to get him on unless you catch him cold on his way home from a score.  46 47 9-to -88 34

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: (continued) ({Halamer nods) Bob isn't really all that bad a guy. He does have a little class and I got to respect him, as much as I hate the sonofabitch. He runs in spurts while he follows his luck and when he's hot he runs like a dog and when he's cold he'll just lay up in some rat hole some Place and you'll never see hide nor hair of him.

dialogues.speaker: HALAMER
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know this guy better than I do.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I've been chasing Bob since he was a kid and hell, he was a pro back then. I think they got him on his first pharmacy when he was thirteen years old. He knows what it's all about, believe me. He can actually smell heat. He probably knows we're sitting out here right now. But if he moves again, we'll be right on his case. Halamer takes a sip of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HALAMER
dialogues.text: What are we going to do in the meantime, just sit out here and freeze our fucking nuts off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A KNOCK comes on the front door of Bob's apartment. The light flashes on and Bob is there quickly with his gun, and Rick is ready to back him up. He opens the peephole and looks out. VIEW through the peephole, a little OLD LADY is standing outside in a bathrobe. BOB'S EXPRESSION of confusion. He let's Rick take a look through the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: As it opens a crack.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Well. I live on the first floor of this building...  48 49 9-10-88 35 Bob keeps opening the door further, then looks from side to side for somebody hiding beside the little old lady.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: ---and I been here for twenty years now. I'm sorry to bother you young folks like this, did I wake you up?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, we was still up.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know what to think, but I was Just getting ready to go to bed and I saw this sinister looking man with a ladder creeping around in the bushes outside. I wonder if you would be so kind as to go out there and look around and see if he's gone. I'm afraid I just couldn't sleep with one of those crazy sex maniacs running loose in the neighborhood. Bob hides a laugh. Rick snickers, but then catches his expression and realizes the possible graveness of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I assure you, ma'am, that I will take a look promptly.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Well, thank you very much. Goodnight. They shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob sits on the sofa and thinks. Nadine bites a hangnail and leans against a wall heater. Rick flexes his muscles for Nadine. DIANNE scratches her head and watches Bob, who is still thinking on the couch. Bob suddenly jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, they must have followed us when we moved, so I guess we'll just have to teach thema little lesson.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEIGHBORHOOD DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is taking a neighborly walk around the neighborhood and inspecting the houses that surround the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: S1A
dialogues.text: 52 9-10-88 36 He walks around the truck parked across from his house. He notices a LARGE BURLY MAN coming out of his house with a sack lunch. The man gets into a large red pickup outside his house and drives off. INT. APARTMENT DAY xe Bob is writing a letter to the narcotics division in printed block letters. Rick looks on. Bob reads the letter outloud as he writes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The reason you can never get Bob Hughes for possession of narcotics is that he has an arrangement with the guy that lives on the north side of him. They have a fishing line running between their houses and Bob signals the guy... OMIT ak INT. COFFEE SHOP DAY (medium close up)

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: ....When he wants the stuff and the next door neighbor puts it on a string and Bob then pulls over what he needs and leaves the rest in the other house where you could never find it. Gentry inspects the handwriting of the note, and seems to question it's validity. DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOB'S APARTMENT DAY
dialogues.text: Bob throws fishing line over to neighbor's house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT DAY
dialogues.text: The big burly next door neighbor is leaving his house again in the morning. Bob is walking toward him from his apartment. His name is GUS HONEYCUT, and he is holding another lunch sack.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Say, pal, you live here?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (shifts lunch from one side to other) Yeah.  9-10-88 37 Bob notices three young daughters watching their father leave for work.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nice weather we're having.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That's a real sharp pickup that you got there. Gus (suspicious) Well thanks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAMPER DAY
dialogues.text: Halamer and Gentry spying on Bob and Gus.

dialogues.speaker: HALAMER
dialogues.text: What d'you suppose he has in that sack, do you think it might be junk?

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I don't know. There's only one thing that I'm positive of.....it's not his goddamn lunch. 52B EXT. GUS'S HOUSE DAY *e

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Say, did you see that fella creeping around your house last night with that ladder? Gus stares at Bob, alarm spreading across his features.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I never would have seen the guy neither but about two o'clock this morning I look out the window and sure enough, there the guy is. A big ugly sonofabitch wearing a long dark trenchcoat and he's standing up on top of his ladder and he's looking in your upstairs windows. Gus looks up at his window, growing very angry and grumbling and looks like he is about to hit Bob. Gus I'll shoot the sonofabitch. I'11 shoot the sonofabitch right in the balls. Bob backs up a bit. This is going to go better than he planned.  52c

dialogues.speaker: HALAMER
dialogues.text: Do you see the way they talk to eachother, all the gestures and such? They got something going, they ain't just casual aquaintances

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, hold on a second mister. I don't want no part of no shooting.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Watch me, just watch me.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have even told you about the guy. In fact, I think I ought to go right now and call the police.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Listen, you little scrawny sonofabitch, I can handle this myself. If you tell one other person about this I'll ring your neck.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Are you threatening me? Gus No, idiot. I'm promising you. Bob turns away and hurries down the sidewalk like he had some place to go.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, for a minute there, I thought that big guy was going to jump on Hughes and stomp him into the sidewalk. I sure would have liked to see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISSOLVE FROM a peaceful daytime shot of the surveillance camper to:  55 56 57 58 59. 60 9-10-88 39

dialogues.speaker: EXT, CAMPER NIGHT
dialogues.text: A serene shot of the camper at night. The same dog barking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halamer is sipping coffee, and TROUSINSKI, a big tough Polish cop is looking over the letter, which Halamer has shown him.

dialogues.speaker: TROUSINSKI
dialogues.text: So that's what's been going on. What a cozy arrangement. No wonder we can never catch that sonofabitch with anything. He's always got the neighbors holding it for him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob peeks out the curtained front window of the apartment and giggles. He closes the curtain and does a little funny dance to himself. He doubles over and makes his way, laughing, to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Close view of Bob's wristwatch, nearing 12:00 ALL FOUR are lined up in front of closed curtains, like a little stage show is going to go on outside, Bob has Placed chairs in a semicircle around the window. He won't let any of the others peek through the curtains, but he regularly does.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just wait. Bob breaks into another laughing fit. Nadine gets upset and gets out of her chair and goes to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gus Honeycut sits in a rocking chair upstairs in his  61 62 63 64 65 66 9-10-88 40 daughter's bedroom with a twelve-gauge automatic shotgun lying across his knees and low-wattage dresser lamp casting a dim light out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halamer and Trousinski (also known as the Strangler) tip-toeing across the lawn quietly. They peer up at the curtained window in Bob's house. VIEW of Bob's window, and then of the uncurtained one nex door. Halamer and Trousinski whisper, but we cannot hear them. Carefully they raise a ladder they are carrying and lean it against the side of Gus' house. This causes a muffled THUMP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus hears the thump outside and starts down the stairs to see what the sound is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Halamer climbs, the Strangler holds the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob pears through the curtains. From where Bob is he can see the ladder, Halamer, Trousinski, and Gus racing down the stairs and out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gus seeing the stationary target at the bottom of the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I'll be a sonofabitch. He aims and FIRES with a WHAMM. The Strangler is blown to the ground and the ladder clamped in his hand comes with him.  67 68 69 70-73 74 75 9-10-88 41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are gathered to see the show, but are bored.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What the hell was that shot? Bob opens the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It's showtime, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and the crew watch the action outside.

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: The blast catches Halamer in the rump and he screams whil he gropes for his gun.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Among Dianne's "Good Lord" and Nadine's “What the heck is going on out there?" we can hear Bob's laugh, above the blasts and confusion. Bob steps behind the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Those cops are gonna be pretty mad now. Let's get the fuck outa here. Tomorrow morning, Rick, you take Nadine and get the car ready, get the thing tuned up and Dianne, get the necessary supplies to make our move. We haven't been cross roading in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sirens can be heard in the background. The little dog barks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sneaks out the front door of his apartment, gets abou halfway down the hallway and is suddenly grabbed from behind and punched, and is SURROUNDED by three PLAIN CLOTHES COPS, one of them is Gentry.  9-10-68 42 Bob is on the ground looking up at them.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Bob, I want to talk about what happened last night.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: We told the investigating officers all we knew about that and we haven't got anything further to add.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: You little punk. Halamer and Trousinski know how you set them up, Bob, and I can honestly say that they are anything but happy about the matter. It took hours for us to pull all that buckshot out of him. Why don't you just go out along the highways and byways of this great grand country of ours until you find a nice spot to settle down somewhere far away from here. A place where narcotics drawers are just brimming to the top with all kinds of goodies laying there waiting for you to take them? How's that sound Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fuck you Gentry. I won the goddamn war, not you. Who are you to dictate the terms? Bob jumps up and tries to get in a punch, but the officer deck him and he is on the ground again.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why don't you find you a small town police department where you can just step in as chief where all you've got to worry about is the usual Saturday night drunks and the kids on Halloween?

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: So you think you won the war, huh? When Halamer and Trousinski get a hold of you, hell, 4t will all be over in a month's time. Oh, yes, we might have to explain it away for a few days, but sooner or later everyone's going to forget that you ever existed. That is, all but the pharmacists. They'll probably hold an annual ball on the eve of your death for the next twenty years. Then Nadine walks around the corner. Gentry and the others help him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 ce GENTRY Let me help you up, Bob. The police leave Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fuck you Gentry, fuck you. I just wish that it had been you out there that caught some of the buckshot. Gentry is already halfway down the hall by the time we se him again. Nadine reaches Bob, who has blood on his mouth and shirt.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: How come you always talk so nasty to those cops? Why don't you talk nice?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Shit! Who ever heard of talking nice toa cop? That crap went out with the forties. I tried talking to a cop nice and respectful once and you know what he did?

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: ce What?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He kicked me in the kneecap, that's what the bastard did.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Well, what did they do when you talked nasty to them?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They kicked me in the kneecap then too, but at least I'm expecting it. Close view of Bob

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, we're going to leave town all right, but don't think any chickenshit cops is running us out of town, because they ain't. It's only because I think it's the smart thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: 76-83 OMIT
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: \ 84 INT. APARTMENT DAY
dialogues.text: HANDS putting drugs in cotton and into small packages and being wrapped.  85 86 87 88 89 9-10-88 44 BOB'S VOICE had to be weil planned The move out of the apartment was-mede—tre series—of-wellmade—meves, the intricacies I would think about all through the night. Dianne had to get all the narcotics together, put some aside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIRDS EYE VIEW of Dianne and Nadine hauling suitcases out the apartment to the car.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...that we would be taking with us then package the rest in individual bags and suitcases...

dialogues.speaker: INT, BUS DEPOT STATION DAY
dialogues.text: Suitcases being weighed for shipment by bus depot EMPLOYEE.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...that would be sent ahead by bus, addressed to various stops on our route. So we could rendezvous with the drugs as we needed them. I had theories about cross-roading, and sending ahead needed drugs was part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ExT. eee eee All FOUR in the car going seventy down a minor highway.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...0ne could not afford to be caught heading across the country with a whole carload of narcotics...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD DAY
dialogues.text: Police car behind road sign, gives chase to Bob's car.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Should any law enforcement officer attempt to stop us...

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR DAY
dialogues.text: Nadine and Rick's hands pull back part of the carpet on the floor of the car, exposing a hole that has been cut there.  90

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...we had a hole punched through the floorboards of our car... BOB'S VIEW out the rear view mirror of a police car, the lights spinning red.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...and when the flashing red light became a reality... Rick and Nadine's hands stuff the drugs out the hole to the moving street below.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: +..we proceeded to dump whatever we had down the hole...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDERNEATH the car, we see pills bouncing off the moving pavement and ricocheting off the muffler, moving wheels, and suspension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob waits for the officer to step to the side of the car. He gives him a very wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is something the trouble officer? Bob gives an oh-so-cheerie smile. And the cop is looking around the inside of the car from the drivers window.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BUS DEPOT DAY
dialogues.text: Bob and Dianne get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...then we would check in at the next rendezvous spot, which hopefully was within eight hours away, before the drugs wore off. EXT. BUS DEPOT DAY #2 (later)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob coming through a revolving door with a suitcase he just picked up.  93 94 9-10-88 46 INT. MOTEL DAY ae Bob is pacing the floor reading from the yellow pages. Rick is lounging on the room's only couch with his head cradled in Nadine's lap. Dianne is in an overstuffed chair rubbing her legs and thighs, wetting her lips, trembling occasionally, and sighing often as if it is the only way she can keep breathing, while she watches Bob pace back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: OWL PHARMACY, Prescription services, Convenient downtown location! Bob rips that page out of the phone book. He puts the book down and reads off some more pharmacies. Nadine looks depressed. She tugs a hangnail on her finger and thinks REAL HARD about something.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay! Let's get off our duffs and out on the road. We ain't going to find no morphine hanging off the fir trees. Dianne, you pick out some doctors and try putting the old headache act on them. Rick and Nadine, you come along with me. We got to find out just what poison shops in this town are holding.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOCTOR'S OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: Dianne waiting in the waiting area of the Doctor's office. She is hiding fidgety signs of drugs, or lack of. But she is made up well. A RECEPTIONIST pushes back a sliding window and pokes out to see Dianne who is wearing dark glasses, looking like a blind person.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Is this your first appointment with Doctor Clark?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I see, will you please £111 out this personal history form? Dianne gets up and takes a form from the Receptionist.  95 96 97 98

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Thank you, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Rick and Nadine in the front seat, Bob driving, and holding the torn Yellow pages in his hand, searching the address out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Are we lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne is led into an examination room by a RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: While you are waiting, you might as well undress and put on the white gown you'll find draped across the stool. The receptionist shuts the door and Dianne whips into action examining the examination room, shaking down CABINETS, DRAWERS, looking for prescription blanks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is pulling to the side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The point is to get the pharmacist to look in his stash for dilaudid tablets...thereby showing us just where the stuff is hid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadine sashays into the store, followed by Rick.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET PHONE BOOTH DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is calling the number from the yellow page in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone ringing as Nadine is trying on lipstick. A PHARMACIST picks up the phone.  100 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, ever-so-politely speaks to the pharmacist.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Say, I've got a one milligram dilaudid prescription and I've been all over town trying to find me some. Could you possibly £111 this prescription for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadine watches the pharmacist through a mirror she is using to try on sample lipstick. The pharmacist changes from a smiling good natured type t a frowning, snarling, no-nonsense masher.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: No, we don't have any dilaudid in any form. We haven't carried any form of that crap in years. So don't bug us anymore. He slams down the phone and looks around his store, an inquisitive CLERK steps closer to the pharmacist.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: What was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Oh, one of those goddamn dope fiends again, asking if we stock one-milligram dilaudid.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We don't have any, do we?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: No, I don't stock the stuff anymore. I used to, but those crazy dope fiends about drove me out of my mind over them... Nadine begins to get a creepy feeling and leaves slowly.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: «.-all day long they were pestering me with phony prescriptions, at night, they crashed through the front door, the back door, through the roof, I expected to find one come crawling down the chimney. Rick and Nadine saunter out the door. The Pharmacist lets out a sigh of relief.  9-10-88 49

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: That was a couple of them right there, I'd bet my bottom dollar on it. Did you see how they stood around trying to look so innocent and prim? They run in packs just like wolves. If you let them think you've got a narcotic drug left on the shelf, they'll pester you until they get it. There isn't anything you can do once they find out you've got what they're after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smiling, middle aged, good natured DOCTOR enters and Dianne is on the table wearing the white nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: And how are you today?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Not too damned good, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: This is your first visit with us, isn't it? He studies her personal history card in his hand. Dianne puts on her most pained expression, blocks her eye from the overhead light.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I have a horrible migrane. Can we turn out the lights, I mean, they're just killing me.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, this is a skylight.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I'm feeling like I'm sick to my stomach. I've taken things for this in the past. Not codeine because I'm allergic to that, but something else.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: But there's this little blue pill, I think it starts with a "d" dilly-something.  103 104 105 106 9-10-88 50

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Dilaudid?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: (hiding her reaction) That's it, Doc. I think that's the one.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DAY
dialogues.text: Nadine and Rick climb into the car with Bob. They are both shaking their heads.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don't look so glum. The bastard's holding all right.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: I don't know, Bob, the clerk asked the pharmacist what it was all about, and he said, "Hell, I haven't seen any dilaudid in years."

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, well they were just putting the shuck on you, because I know the bastards had dilaudid in there not too awful long ago, and besides, they wouldn't have gotten so paranoid if they wasn't holding. Bob checks another pharmacy on the yellow pages list. EXT. OK USED CARS DAY ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is signing a paper on the hood of a red pickup truck.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Now the reason that we have this truck is not because we necessarily need another vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RED PICKUP NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob is lecturing Nadine and Rick.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: But we can move easier, in this sort of a vehicle. We also have the right license plates on our ass, so's the average Joe thinks that we're farmers just in town for a little ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, Nadine and Rick get out of the red pickup and walk into a bar.  107 108 109 9-10-88 51

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Now, there's always something that you can pick up if you keep your eyes open. Sometimes it is so obvious it escapes the casual observer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRUCK NIGHT
dialogues.text: The truck is driving down the street.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You gotta keep on the lookout, because you never know what you might find. EXT. STREET NIGHT ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, Nadine and Rick walking by a darkened drug store.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Did you see that? Everyone is still walking.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What? Rick and Nadine turn their heads to see what they have missed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The transoms, didn't you guys see the open transoms?

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What are transoms?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Those little windows open above the front door, Rick. Wow! What a birds nest on the ground, and you guys never even saw it. (pointing) You got to keep your eyes open, you got to look. Bob whistles.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And that nasty-assed bastard pharmacist saying "No, we don't have no dilaudid, haven't stocked that crap in years". Well, well, we'll just see 1£ that bastard wasn't lying through his teeth or not, right this goddamn minute. Rick you go back to the pickup and get that small bar I shoved under the front seat. Bob and Nadine walk away arm in arm. Bob flirting with Nadine. Bob Nadine and I will walk around a bit and see what all is happening on this street. See if there's any drunks or couples sitting around in any of these cars parked along here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick fetching the bar from the front seat of the truck an walking back Bob's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick meets up with Bob and Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
