dialogues.text: Okay, Rick here's the play. We get the traffic right first, then we move over in front of those open transoms. You cup your hands, I stick my foot in, you lift, up I go. Rick nods.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll let you in the back door and we can amble over to the truck, in back of the Pharmacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Rick move fast, step up under the pharmacy's entrance and Rick lifts while Bob pulls, up and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob whirls and races along the shelves until he comes to locked door leading to a back room. With a deft movement, Bob springs the door in a matter of seconds.  113 114 115 116 117 9-10-88 53

dialogues.speaker: INT. BACK ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob is in an area that is divided by rough-cut dirty, age wood. Two safes are against one wall. Also there is an alley entrance which has a huge sliding wooden door, secured by a padlock, Bob tears off the padlock to ensure a quick exit. NEXT, in the other section of the room, encased in aluminum and glass, 1s the back of the pharmacy, Bob ATTACKS a small sliding door and enters, moving quickly along the shelves of pills and halfway along the main counter he finds a locked drawer. It isn't too large but... WHEN HE SPRINGS IT OPEN he finds it heaped to the brim with different bottles of different colors and designs, and all of them have a purple federal stamp on the cap. BOB GRINS. He grabs the whole drawer and runs for the alley exit.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PHARMACY REAR DOOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: EXT. PRR eee Bob slides open the door where Rick and Nadine are waitin Bob hands Nadine the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: fake this, baby, and put it in the truck. Rick, step inside here a moment. I want you to look at these two safes. MOVING VIEW of Nadine running with the drawer, clutching tt to her stomach like a cigarette girl. She runs so hard she sounds like a milk truck beginning its delivery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadine arrives at the truck and hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PHARMACY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob is watching Nadine and the truck.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PHARMACY BACK ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: iNT. Frankie Rick steps up to the safes.  118 119 120 121 9-10-88 54

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRUCK NIGHT
dialogues.text: Nadine stands beside the truck.

dialogues.speaker: BOB WATCHING
dialogues.text: Nadine starts to lower the whole drawer into the bed of the truck, then lets it rest on the truck's side panel while she opens the door of the truck. Nadine then grabs the drawer, swings it backward as far a her arms can go and brings the drawer forward as if she i a fish wife emptying a pan of water, spilling the bottles all over the seat and floor of the truck. Bob can't believe what he's seeing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PHARMACY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rick and the safes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Rick, forget about the safes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PHARMACY BACK DOOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rick emerges from the pharmacy. They close the back door and both take off running toward Nadine and the pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadine bends down with the empty drawer between her legs then straightens up, flipping the drawer up and over her head. It sails into the air... SPINS AROUND a few times and lands in the street a few parking meters away. A small grey VOLKSWAGEN rounds a corner and slows down near the drawer, seemingly studying it momentarily, then it drives on. ANOTHER CAR is coming as Bob and Rick reach shaking Nadine. They quickly push her into the pickup and Bob pulls away, sitting on a pile of bottles, for once saying absolutely nothing.  122 123 124

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: The truck is taking corner after corner.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRUCK NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob and Rick and Nadine as the truck takes another corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck pulls to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's get all these bottles together, put them in a sack and you, Nadine, you take that sack and walk over to those bushes along side that house and wait for us while we go back and get that drawer and clean it up. You didn't have any gloves on and, baby, that clean cream drawer is going to have nothing but your fingerprints all over it. It takes a second to get all the bottles together. INT. TRUCK NIGHT (later)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck is moving. Bob and Rick breathe a sigh of relief as the headlights of the truck spotlight the drawe in front of them. Rick jumps out of the truck and picks up the drawer and gets back in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Rick and Nadine have entered, Dianne comes into the room to see what they found, but Nadine doesn't stay, she marches back to her room and slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What's that all about? Bob is inspecting the bottles in the bag and bringing the out one by one.  9-10-88 56

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: (still interested in Nadine) You been making a pass at her again, Bob? Bob shakes his head and paws through the pile of small bottles. He comes up with a small one with a blue label.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll be goddamned.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What is it, Bob? What did you find?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Powdered dilaudid, that's what. A whole untouched one eighth ounce bottle of powdered D. And there should be another partially filled bottle here somewhere. Bob spreads them all out on the coffee table and separate them into different categories.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know what this bottle is worth, Rick? He holds up the bottle that is only two inches high. Rick shakes his head as he takes the bottle from Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you what it's worth. It's worth a goddamn fortune, at least a small fortune. That there's got eight hundred and forty some odd sixteenths in it, and at ten dollars a sixteenth, that comes to around eight thousand four hundred dollars worth of the best goddamn dope money can buy. Slaps his leg.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Hot dog, what a find, yep, that there little bottle will probably last us three for a week. I guess we must have outrun that hex we had on us. I sure an glad we started cross-roading, aren't you, Bob? And Bob takes a willing Dianne in his arms and whirls her around the room, as she squeals and shrieks in delight.  127 128 129 9-10-88 57

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Nadine sits in silence at the edge of her bed. Her coat is still on and tears are slowly coursing down her cheeks DIANNE'S SCREAM can be heard in the next room, Rick and Bob are shouting with joy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob jumps up. Rick is fixing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay, pards, I'l] show you how we'll hide this stuff in these motels. Open up that trap door to the attic, and I'll push you on up through. You cross over a couple of these units and stash the stuff over somebody else's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick enters the room and stands awhile just inside the door watching Nadine. She is still on the bed with her coat on and her head lowered.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Buck up, baby. So you muffed it, everyone does that once in awhile. It came out all right and that's what counts. We're going to go out again, but don't worry, we'll be back soon. Nadine raises a tear stained face.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: What did that sonofabitch say about me?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Baby, he didn't say anything. Not one word. Dianne doesn't even know anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: But he isn't going to take me along anymore. Is that it? And one day you all will just drop me off on a corner and tell me to do such such and I'll come back and wait and wait and you'll never show up. THEN her voice breaks into sobs and the trail of tears become a flood. Rick kneels beside her.  9-10-88 58

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Baby, we ain't going to leave you standing on no corner. We ain't leaving you any place. You're mine, baby. I'm not leaving you. Bob is no doubt leaving you home tonight because you are feeling bad. He knows how bad you feel about the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: To hell with that sonofabitch and his hexes and all his funny little stunts. It wasn't my fault he had to leave the coast. That was his fault. The goddamn hog.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Now, baby, you just take it easy, we got us a good thing going. Why break it up? Tomorrow you will see things in a different light. You're all upset. It'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: No Rick, it's not going to be fine. I just can't stand their superior ways and all that crap about hexes. You don't believe that stuff, do you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't know, Nadine. What difference does it make? It's their thing. I guess if they want to believe in hexes, they're entitled to. All we got to watch is not talking about pets in their presence and not leaving any hats on any bed. Hell there's nothing hard about that.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just going to prove to all of you that there isn't anything to any of that stuff. Nadine marches to the closet and promptly takes out one o her hats. She determinedly flips it onto the bed and then asks Rick:

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Do you think it will make any difference that I'm using a woman's hat instead of a man's? Rick shakes his head slowly.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn't of done that, Nadine. It really isn't fair. I mean, you can do whatever you want to change our lives, but what do you want to mess with someone else's for? That don't seem quite right.  130 131 132 9-10-88 59

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: To hell with them. I'm going to leave that hat right there. You go on out with them tonight. rm going to show them it don't mean nothing at a . Rick shakes his head again. He lays an outfit anda couple of sixteenth down on the night stand.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I think they want to go right away. We won't be long, maybe a couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick breaks into a car in the hospital parking lot. Bob and Dianne kiss before he takes off. Dianne watches from her stolen car as Rick, in his car heads right between two parked police cars ata hair-raising thirty-five miles an hour. Only three feet separates the two cars, so Rick gets both of their rear fenders in the initial rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the HOSPITAL it is like one continuous corridor, broken up at intervals by little substations, which are composed of a waist high counter enclosing a switchboard, a few desks and an aid station of sorts. There are a couple of NURSES hanging around the substations. A POLICEMAN is in the corridor. OUTSIDE we can hear the sound of cars revving their engines, and horns BLARING and metal SMASHING. The policeman and the nurses go to the front windows of the corridor to see what the problem is. THEIR VIEW from through the window of the parking lot. TWO CARS are running amok in the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he throws the car in reverse, and floorboards the accelerator. His car clings to the smashed police cars for a second while his tires scream and pour out smoke. then abruptly, the torn and intermeshed metal of the cars separates and away Rick roars again until he comes to a halt forty feet away against another late model car. VIEW of the Hospital, people are hanging out the windows watching.  133 134 135 9-10-88 60 Rick keeps right on working, he gives the police another shot for good measure, then he picks out an automobile behind and off to one side and gives it a bank shot that crumples the right front fender. TWO POLICEMEN come running from the front doors of the hospital. They run across the front lawn less than a hundred yards away from Rick. Then Dianne gets into the act. She holds her horn down causing one continuous blast, and squeals out of her position toward the officers, who are running after Rick. VIEW of Dianne closing in on the officers, who take a div to the ground. Dianne keeps going until she comes to Rick, who has ditched his car and is now on foot. She stops momentarily to let Rick in, then turns and takes off burning rubber all the way out of the parking lot. BOB SEES and HEARS the pandemonium from where he is hidin up against the side of the building.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They'll probably talk about this one for years. He smiles and quickly smashes out a window and climbs int a vacant office.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob coming through the window of a darkened office. He crosses the room, sticks his head out the door into a lon corridor, and:

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: NOT SEEING ANYBODY, steps across the corridor to the locked entrance of the PHARMACY. After studying the door momentarily, he takes a small pry bar, slams the tapered end into the crack between the door and the jam at lock level, and SNAPS the other end of the bar back. The door shoots open with a noise resembling a muffled shot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PHARMACY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob: quickly enters and braces the door behind him. It stays in position, but with a piece of the jam gone, then  136 137 9-10-88 61 he goes directly to the narcotics cabinets housed behind counter. The lockers are made of one-eighth inch sheet steel and have large brass padlocks on them. Bob tries to wedge his pry bar between the bolt of a lock but the bar is too big. Next he tries to wedge it between the lock and the hasp, but the bar slips out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fuck it! The sweat is pouring down Bob's face in rivulets, his clothes are damp and his hands are beginning to shake. He tries forcing the bar into the crack beside the cabine door, but the bar jumps toward him every time he applies pressure. He tries lifting the cabinet free from the wall, but it i solid. He jams the pry bar between the wall and the cabinet and gives a mighty heave. The cabinet bends toward him, but it's obvious that this will take too long Bob stands back from the cabinets and brings the wedge shaped point of the bar down in a cutting motion in an attempt to tear a hole in the sheet metal and more or les can-open the thing enough to reach inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: INT. CORRIOUR Rives A nurse hears the noise as she passes by. She tries to open the door but it is jammed. She pulls her ear to the door and listens, then she runs down the hall for help.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PHARMACY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob has one of the cabinets open only to find Demerol (otherwise known to drug addicts as "dummy 0i1")

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: ugh! He raises his pry-bar to go for another cabinet when the door of the pharmacy breaks open behind the weight of .TW BURLY ATTENDANTS. They hurl themselves into the room, take one look at Bob and immediately begin closing in.  138 139 140 141 142 143 9-10-88 62 Bob swings his bar at them, and leaps over to a window overlooking one of the quaint little gardens in the hospital courtyard. With one swing of the bar, he smashes out the window and dives through it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOSPITAL COURTYARD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob lands on the sidewalk in a roll and when he scrambles to his feet, blood is streaming down his face. Above him the attendant is trying to climb out the window Bob gives him a mild bop on the head with his bar and the attendant starts climbing back in. Bob heads for an exit door to another wing. The exit door is locked. Bob smashes a hole through the glass top of the door, reaches in to open it from the inside, and heads down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: He tries wiping blood from his face as he makes his way down the corridor. He disappears into a women's restroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob stands in front of a mirror and examines the damage t his head. He watches the blood pump out in small but steady streams He washes off his face and hands, and puts paper towels t the wound. He wipes up the sink and the mirror and then retreats to a toilet booth.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOILET NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob sits down and waits.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dianne and Rick in their own car, waiting beneath a large tree, somewhere near the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dianne is fidgeting.  144 145 146 147 148 9-10-88 63

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Bob's like a rabbit, in and out and no nonsense. And that goes for a lot more than just a hospital pharmacy. This just isn't like him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WOMAN'S ROOM TOILET NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob waiting. A woman comes in and uses the next stall. Bob gets up on the toilet so she doesn't see him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAR NIGHT
dialogues.text: The car beneath the tree waiting.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAR DAWN
dialogues.text: The car still waiting, only the sun is coming up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR DAWN
dialogues.text: Dianne and Rick waiting, and yawning.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: We might as well give up. He ain't coming.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: (grabs Rick) They got him. The bastards got him. I know it. I can feel it in my heart. The bastards, the dirty bastards. If they've hurt him just one little bit, I'11 kill. I'11 kill them all! Dianne starts to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Dianne enter, it is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: iNT. PERRee ee Rick opens the bedroom door and notices that the hat is still on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadine is nowhere to be seen. Rick steps over to the closet. Then he sees something. NADINE'S FEET are sticking out from the floor on the othe side of the bed. Her lips and face are a funny bluish color. An outfit hangs out of a ditch in her arm.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! He falls to his knees to hold her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. I never should have gotten you into all this. Rick holds her and moans.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, baby, please, baby, what can I do? Dianne enters and sees the situation. She huddles over Rick, just as:

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM be Bob comes happily in the front door whistling. His face and upper forehead and one arm are covered with white medical tape and bandages.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Honey! I'm home!

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Bob joins his crew.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What in the hell is going on? Dianne turns and looks at Bob's bedraggled appearance.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What did the bastards do to you? What did they do, I'l] kill them, 1'11 kill them...  9-10-88 65

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who put that hat on that goddamned bed?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: She did, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (seeing Nadine) What?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: She didn't mean no harm by it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She bit it.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: She said it was bullshit! Oh, it's all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who gave her the stuff, she couldn't have done that on no two-sixteenths. What's she been doing, saving it up? Bob picks up a bottle beside the bed, the small blue partially filled one. Bob shakes Rick takes

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Where in the hell did she get this?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I knew there should have been another opened bottle. She must've picked it up while we were collecting the bottles off the floor of the truck. Stupid conniving bitch.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (angry, jumping up off the corpse) You can't call her that. She's dead. Don't ever say anything bad about her. his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She beat you, man. Your own woman beat you out of part of your own cut on a score. She got what she deserves. a swing at Bob but misses and sends his hand through a plaster wall.  152 153 Cr 154 9-10-88 66

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Not only that, the dumb bitch threw a hex on us that we'll all be lucky to survive. And she left us with and 0.D.'d stiff which, if I'm not mistaken, is paramount to a murder beef in this state. And for Christsakes get that hat off the bed. Bob kicks the hat off the bed and backs out of the room away from Rick who is pulling his hand out of the wall. Dianne is clinging to Bob's arm. Bob slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: How did you ever get away?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I hid in a woman's restroom. When I woke up and left, I ran into a nurse and gave her a story that I was looking for the emergency room. They fixed me up pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB AND DIANNE'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Bob and Dianne are looking up at the celling, lying in bed. :

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I know what. Let's pull her up into the attic and hide her there for the day. At least then the maid won't be stumbling over her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know what, Dianne? That's probably the best idea you've come up with in years.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RICK AND NADINE'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Bob and Dianne enter. Rick is kneeling on the floor with his head down on the bed as though he is in prayer. Bob walks up to him cautiously, takes him by the shoulders an stands him up and hugs him, then walks him out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: We got to get Rick here in bed. He's been up all night and probably don't know what the hell he's doing, do you, Rick?  155 156 157

dialogues.speaker: INT. CRAWLSPACE DAY
dialogues.text: The wooden hatch to the crawlspace opens. Dianne is ona chair looking up at OUR VIEW and Bob is below her with Nadine's body over his shoulder in a fireman's lift.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Nadine's legs sticking down out of the crawlspace, Dianne still below on the chair guiding her up, Bob out of sight in the crawlspace. The worst part of the job having passed without our seein it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hatch is closing, the VIEW pans over to see Nadine's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne replaces the chair where it usually is.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hell, it's like trying to raise a couple of goddamn kids when you take on a couple like that and try and teach them to steal. Do you know that, Dianne? It's just like raising children. All the hassles, all the petty Jealousies, all the what-ifs.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: You aren't kidding.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm getting too old for this shit. These goddamn kids today, they ain't got no sense at all. They're all TV babies. They been watching people killing and fucking each other on that goddamn boob tube and that's all they know. Hell, they think it's legal, that it's the right thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Relax hon. You can't take on the whole world. THE DOORBELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wow, what a busy day.  9-10-88 68 Bob checks the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I think it's the guy from the front desk. Bob slowly opens the door. A uniformed MOTEL MANAGER is outside. Bob closes

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hello, are you Mr. Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Are you planning on checking out today?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, sir, but when you registered, we asked you how long you intended to stay and you said a couple of days. We had prior commitments in the form of a reservation for your room today.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You mean I got to move out right now?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Well, you see, I'm afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well you just listen here. One of our colleagues is very sick and I just don't feel that we want to up and try to move to another motel...

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Well, you see, they're having a sheriff's convention here in town and all these rooms have been reserved for them as long as ninety days ago.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Let me come down to the office in a minute. I'll be right down. the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They're having a sheriff's convention.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: We're going to know some of those guys, I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, a sheriff's convention, no less. Why couldn't it be a pharmacist's convention?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Or better yet, an undertaker's.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL DAY
dialogues.text: Bob walks into the office.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: The stately smiling MANAGER is behind the counter. Bob is standing in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Mr. Hughes, you should have let us know you intended staying this long. We'd have warned you of our commitments.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I got a colleague in that motel room that's got the mumps, I'm scared to move him. What if they should spread. Hell, we'd hit you with a law suit that would ruin you. Now can't you juggle those rooms around a bit or get the intendeds a reservation somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Well, if that's the case, you go on back to your room. (a beat) Perhaps we can reserve them a room somewhere else just for this one night. You will have to leave tomorrow. Bob walks out of the office. Just as a SHERIFF walks in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL DAY
dialogues.text: Bob walking back to his room. POLICE SHERIFFS are beginning to pull into the motel parking lot. Other SHERIFFS are talking down at the end of the walkway.  160 161 9-10-88 70

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Bob shuts the door behind him. Dianne and Rick are on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It looks like a fucking sheriffs convention out there. but they're going to let us keep the room one more night.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Good God, how are we ever going to get her out of here with the place full of drunken cops coming and going all night?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Maybe we could just head on out and leave her up there.

dialogues.speaker: _ BOB
dialogues.text: (astounded) Are you mad, Dianne? She'd be oozing down out of the attic in less than a week. These people around here have seen her. They're going to remember that she was with us. No we got to get her out tonight. INT. MOTEL DAY (later)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Dianne sitting across from each other. Bob is showing signs of wear.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: It's gonna be one heck of a time getting her outta that crawlspace... Bob just looks at the floor, doesn't say a word.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Don't know if I'm ever going to get my nails done now... Dianne watches Bob watching the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Nadine really got to you didn't she, Bob? Bob considers the question for awhile, then looks straight at Dianne for the first time that afternoon.  tf 9-10-88 71

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, I suppose you could say that. I'm not exactly thrilled over her having left us in such an abrupt manner.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I don't mean that, Bob. I've seen you around other overdose cases and you never got like this.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, just different.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, well 1'11 tell you what's wrong. I'm scared to fucking death that some big fucking cop is going to come rumbling through that door any minute and say, "Out this is my fucking room, out." (long pause) Do we have that garment bag in the car?

dialogues.speaker: INT. CRAWLSPACE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The hatch to the crawlspace opens and Bob hoists himself up into it. Nadine's HORRIBLE EXPRESSION of fear and happiness strikes Bob as he begins to handle the body. The body is very stiff, and like a mannequin. They have to lower Nadine head first down the hole.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dianne is ready to catch Nadine who is coming down head first, but Dianne buckles under the weight of Nadine and falls with her into the closet with a crash. BOB'S VIEW through the crawlspace as he watches Dianne and Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: God what a hassle. Bob wipes his brow.

dialogues.speaker: INT, MOTEL EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Bob zips Nadine into garment bag. Bob parts the curtains of the front window of the motel room. OUTSIDE it is a sea of COP CARS. It looks like his car and the pickup are the only ones that don't have radio antennas and red lights sticking out all over them.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (to Dianne) You go first, unlock the car. Look around a bit while you're doing it. See if anyone is lurking about. Dianne puts her coat on, smiles, turns to the door and heads for the parking lot. Bob stands and fidgets in front of the curtains, not watching Dianne in the parking lot. He can hear the trunk of the car open. Then a few seconds later Dianne returns.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: We're all set, the car door's open and I didn't see anyone at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob crosses the parking lot with Nadine over his shoulder, making it seem like she doesn't weigh a thing. He puts Nadine in the trunk and returns to the room. In front of their room is a suspicious cop. Bob ad libs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Did you remember the diapers, hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob enters, a little winded.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wow, what a drag. I mean, that broad was heavy. You're right, she would have been fat in a couple of years. Jesus, I'm glad she decided to go and do her thing now instead of waiting until then. I'd of never made it. Bob looks at Dianne and tried to grin but it didn't come out quite right. He looked like a little kid about to bawl.  9-10-88 73

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How about going up in the attic and getting out our stuff and dividing it up. We'll give Rick the car and the stuff we sent ahead to those bus depots. Figure it all out. Don't count him short. Give him the big end. Dianne stared at Bob until he turned away.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What are you thinking about doing, Bob? What you got on your mind? Bob let his eyes slide around the room evasively, he started to Bob slowly speak a couple of times then said nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The thing is I've been thinking about heading on back to the coast. I think maybe I'll go on down and get on that twenty-one day methadone withdrawal program, get my head together.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No I'm not, Dianne. I can't do it anymore. shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not going on no withdrawal program, so what's going to happen to me?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why can't you come along?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I don't want to. You know I've tried that and it doesn't work for me.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Do whatever you want, Dianne. Bob looks around.  172 173 174 175 176 9-10-88 74

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Take whatever you need or whatever we got. I only need enough to get me to the coast. Dianne is acting like she doesn't know whether to believe her man or not, knowing that this is the end of their relationship if Bob goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls over to the side of a long road. A heavily wooded area {s to one side. The pickup truck pulls up behind the car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRUCK DAY
dialogues.text: Bob thinks for a second, then speaks just as he gets out of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Get the shovel, Dianne. I'11l handle her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD DAY
dialogues.text: Bob skips up to the side of the car, Rick is driving.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You, Rick, stay here and see that nobody comes along and wants to know if we're having a picnic or something.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is carrying Nadine through the woods. Dianne is following. At one point he stops carrying her on his shoulder, puts her down and drags her while she is still in the clothing bag.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is digging a hole, he keeps chopping and hammering at roots that are too stubborn to be dug up. Dianne walks away.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Nadine, if I'd have known this was going to happen then I would never had let you come along.  177 178 179 180 9-10-66 75

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS DAY
dialogues.text: Nadine's body goes in the hole. Bob unzips the bag and takes a look at Nadine before he covers her up. He remarks at two leaves that are covering her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, Nadine, it's every man and woman for his or her self. And it's time for your old friend Bob to take off. Maybe I'm changing in my Autumn years. ‘Cause I don't want to happen to me what's happened to you. Bob looks back to Dianne and Rick then back at Nadine.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And Dianne, I don't think that she can put up with the straight life. So I guess I'm going alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is finishing the job, then he randomly walks around breaking sticks and things in a temper. Then he stops, calming himself, gathering his thoughts, and marches out of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks out of the woods. Dianne is by the side of the road, and Rick is inside of the car. Bob opens the rear door of the car and gets his clothes out of the back and puts them in the back of the truck. He pauses, not looking at Dianne or Rick, but aware that they are watching him. Bob can't look back at Dianne.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR DAY
dialogues.text: Rick watches through his rear view mirror.  181 182

dialogues.speaker: 182B
dialogues.text: 183 9-10-88 76 Dianne walks up to the side window of the car.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What's happening, what's all the fuss? Dianne bends down to the driver's window and smiles at Rick.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't know. - But let's just start worrying about us. Now I know you're ten years younger than I am, but I'm not looking for romance anyway. I'm looking for someone with guts. You get you an old lady, and I'll get me an old man, and we won't pick them because they're beautiful people, we'll pick the ones that will make the best thieves in our helling crew, and baby, everyone will dive on this crew. It won't be no one man show. Dianne turns around and runs to the other side of the car and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, well, they say that God looks out for drunks and fools, and He sure enough looked out for Bob on occasion, and maybe He'd look out for him now too.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD DAY
dialogues.text: They take off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AVIS RENTAL DAY
dialogues.text: Bob checks in the red pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks across the lot to the Bus Depot.

dialogues.speaker: NT. CAR DAY
dialogues.text: Rick tunelessly whistles as Dianne runs through a list of people and their whereabouts; they need for a crew.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BUS DAY
dialogues.text: OUT THE WINDOW of the bus, a moving countryside with rolling hills, rivers, mountains.  9-10-88 77 Bob SMILES at the countryside. The voice of GENTRY, the police lieutenant, is heard.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Looks like you're hooked to the gills, and we got witnesses this time Bob. DOUBLE EXPOSED over Bob's smile is Gentry, saying these words in the back of the surveillance camper. Gentry's EXPOSURE has given way the THE HAT; Bob's smile remains in the corner of the screen; and Dianne is seen as well.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Why a hat?

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You just put a thirty day hex on us.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE'S SMART SISTER
dialogues.text: Why don't you just leave Dianne, Bob, and go join one of those female impersonator clubs? You shouldn't have any trouble at at all getting a membership from what I can see, and you'd no doubt be happy learning to enjoy contributing to a normal segment of our community.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Dianne could put up with anything from her man as long as he was a successful drug thief. Bob's smile, it is beginning to mouth the name Dianne, over the moving countryside out of the window, and an exposure of the hat having disappeared. Images of Dianne flash over the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: She doesn't particularly care what her man looks like, how he acts or what he says to her during breakfast. Like other women she loves a man who can produce, and she loves with great intensity. She'll spit in a cop's eye in a minute. She's virtually fearless in all respects. But if he doesn't produce, well then, that's it; goodbye to her man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's face can be seen reflecting off the window over the passing landscape, the sun settling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob watches out the window. A bright drive in passes by.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BUS NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob looks around the bus. He's showing signs of withdrawal. Sitting across the aisle from him is a darling old grandma knitting.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Isn't she a cute old grandma? Knitting so fastidiously. To look at her one wouldn't think she had ever done anything in her whole life but raise her children and her children's children. But who knows, she might have been a hooker and a bawdy dancer in Alaska during the gold rush. She could have murdered fourteen people and skinned them alive for all anyone knew. But right now, right this minute, she is a darling old grandma and most likely that's all she's ever been. Have any of these passengers been in as insane a situation as I am in now? VIEW of a rumpled drunk guy sitting in back of Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Now take that guy sittin there. He's half crocked now, rumpled and grubby as any bum on skid row. And who was he? He could very easily have been an upstanding businessman just a few years ago. Plenty of the bums and winos of today were just that not so long ago. Or he might have been a hit man for the Mafia. Bob grins at his fantasizing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But he sure has everyone fooled now.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD DAY
dialogues.text: The bus going down the road.  187 188 9-10-88 79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is looking up at the front door of the center.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CENTER DAY
dialogues.text: Bob sitting uncomfortably in a chair across from an older woman sitting at a desk in her office. Bob looking sick. A name tag on her desk reads MRS. WATERMAKER.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Well, young man, what can we do for you this morning?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I want to sign up for your withdrawal program.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: I see. And when was the last time you took whatever you use?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Night before last.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Are you going to get violently sick today then? You realize that to get right on the withdrawal program that you have to be in the third stage of withdrawal, sweating, stomach cramps...chills...temperature, and so on?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Have you ever been on either the maintenance or withdrawal program before?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: I see. Now how long have you been addicted to whatever you're on now? .

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: This time?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Then this isn't your first time withdrawing?  9-10-68 80

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, but it's my first time withdrawing on methadone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: I see. Well, how long have you been using drugs altogether?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: All my life.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: All your life? A little skepticism flashes across Mrs. Watermaker's face.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, since I've been twelve or thirteen I've been using narcotics. I guess you could say that was all my life.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: How old are you now?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Twenty six.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Why do you want to quit now, after all that time? I'd think you'd be inclined to go right on with it. Why quit now? Bob shrugged and grinned.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know, curiosity I guess. I just thought I'd try it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Are you serious? I mean, we get a lot of guys and gals coming up here just trying to get in on a new kick and that's not what we're here for.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, lady, you just found you one of those people what ain't got any other way to turn, so give me a jolt and let me go on my merry way.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Oh, my, it's not that easy, young man. You've got all kinds of paperwork to £111 out.  189 190 191 9-10-88 81

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: (continued) You've got a doctor's examination to go through and then maybe, just maybe, we'll help you out. You've got to get sick first too, you know. Bob grins and throws up on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is washing his face. He looks up at the ceiling. He listens to a song on a radio.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. METHADONE CLINIC DAY
dialogues.text: EXT. ME THADUNS Ch ihey ei Clouds part over the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is in a chair talking again to Mrs. Watermaker.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Let me see now, I wanted to ask you a few things before we go on much further. Let's see, are you married?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Where is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: _ BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Hmm, I see. Do you have any children?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Do you have a job?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Do you have a social security number?  yrau-bo 82

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I see, have you ever been convicted of a felony?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes. A few times.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: What were they? What kind of felonies were you convicted of?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, burglary, robbery, possession, grand theft, stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: And how much time have you spent in prison?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know. Twelve years more or less I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Well, then, you haven't been an addict all your life then, have you, Mr. Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: I mean you could hardly have been an addict in prison now, could you Mr. Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Do you mean to sit there and tell me that you were addicted to drugs while in prison?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, not all the time. But I used all the time I was inside, I mean, what do you want, lady, my life story? Well, I'll tell it to you. I was a junkie. I liked dope. I liked the lifestyle. I was on top of it all but it wasn't real. You don't see my kind of people, because my kind of people don't come down here and beg dope. They go out and get it and if they miss, they go to jail and then they kick alone without nothing in some holding tank.  192 y-ib-b6 83

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Bob. I don't mean to hassle you. All this is required. I'm sorry if it seems unnecessary. Have you ever thought about becoming a counselor and helping other addicts with their problems?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (without hesitation) No, I don't think so, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, to begin with, no one, and I mean no one can talk a junkie out of using, so all your counseling is just wasted words and you might as well have flushed them down the toilet. A junkie needs his thing nine times out of ten just to be able to live with himself. He needs it just like a diabetic needs insulin. How are you going to sit and talk a diabetic out of using insulin?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATERMAKER
dialogues.text: Hmmm, I see, well, tell me, Bob, if you can, why did you use narcotics? Bob sits and squirms in his chair. He looks out the office window.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That really is a tough question, lady. I may think I know the answer, and then maybe I don't. When you ask a dope fiend why he uses, it's just about like asking a normal person why they like sex. And I suppose different people will come up with different answers, ranging from it just feels good, to I can't resist the urge, to it's all part of love, to I only do it to have children. Lady, a dope fiend will give you just about the same answers, with the exception of the last one. I've yet to hear a dope fiend claim he shot dope in an attempt to have children. INT. HOTEL LOBBY DAY ex Bob is sitting by the window, watching cars and people go by outside. The elevator doors open and TOM walks out, past the hotel desk, where a tall, cadaverish CLERK is sorting mail. The Clerk sees Tom.  9-10-88 84

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Hey Tom, there's a letter for you here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (accepting the letter) Bless you. Tom opens it, walking across the lobby to the chairs by the window, and sits down to read. Bob has recognized him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Father Murphy? Hey, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (peering at Bob) Well, well. . . bad Bobby Hughes. Imagine seeing you here after all these years.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's been a long time. You living here too?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I have nowhere else to go. There is no demand in the priesthood for elderly drug addicts. An indiscretion back in '70 -- you were "inside" at the time, I believe -- resulted in my descent to this sorry state. As a matter of fact I am feeling a bit sick right now. Are you holding?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Naw, I am kicking like a goddamn mule. Those bastards at the methadone clinic want me good and sick before they'll process my application. But you ought to be able to get on easy?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (absently tearing bits of paper from the letter) Sure I'm on the program. But sometimes I get a little ahead of my schedule, you understand. Sometimes I think that nurse is lightening them up, but who knows. So how about it, you want to score?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Not me, Tom. But I'll keep you company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 193 9-10-68 EXT PARK DAY ae Bob and Tom sitting on park bench. INT. TOM'S ROOM DAY ae Tom and Bob are sitting in the small room, talking.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: « . ». SO they are cooking up the shot ina big spoon and this little guy that was sitting in the corner, you wouldn't notice him, is standing there with one foot off the ground, like he's going to kick the spoon out of their hands, and he says, "Draw my shot up nice and easy, or it ain't nobody gets any." And it's a bluff they don't care to call. So they give him his shot, and he goes back off in the corner to enjoy his medications.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: And they didn't kick his ass.?!

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What's the point? These junkies, they figure the little guy made his play, he had the guts, what the hell. They understand. And, after that, they watched him closer.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know, Tom, you taught me a lot, like stay out of a boy and girl fight. All the old time stories, how yoou used to stick your arm through the bars of the cell and a guard would fire you up a shot of morphine. They never did that for me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Narcotics have been demonized and scapegoated in this country. To those who do not use, it is a sin, or a crime, or an illness. The very idea that anyone could use drugs and avoid a horrible fate is anathema to these idiots. They are morally ravaged victims of the Right Virus, and they seem to have the whip hand on planet Earth, at the present time. In the future I predict they will exploit a domestic drug panic as a masquerade behind which to prop up their international police state. But I'm an old man, and maybe I won't live to see the whole shithouse go up. 85  194

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You missed your calling, Tom. You should have been a philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: In another life perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob at work, he is drilling holes into a metal plate, then measuring the holes, and checking for burrs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is walking cheerily down the street, wearing some new clothes. David walks out of a doorway after Bob passes, not taking too much notice of Bob, but aware that he passed by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob cooking soup that he has still in the can. LATER, Bob eating under a small light, while sitting on his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holes being drilled.

dialogues.speaker: INT. METHADONE CLINIC DAY
dialogues.text: Bob sitting in a group. A discussion group.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HANDBALL COURT _DAY
dialogues.text: Bob playing handball on outside court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob reaches the hallway to his own room and goes inside, after unlocking the door.  196 9-10-88 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob closes the door and locks it, but sitting behind him is Detective GENTRY, in a chair next to the bed, under a reading lamp. Bob smoothly takes off his coat and hangs it up. (Nothing to hide attitude)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Catching up on some reading, Gentry? Gentry ignores the remark.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: You didn't stay gone long, Bob, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nothing happened. Bob plops onto his bed and braces his hands behind his head.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I hear you're on a methadone program now. Now you don't think that's going to keep Halamer from jumping you, do you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: To tell the truth, I hadn't given it much thought.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Well, I want to tell you, warn you, that Halamer's pissed. He lost his gold badge, you know, over that little fracas. He's now working traffic out in the north end. He's made so many damn threats, told so many people that he's almost going to have to hurt you now.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What about the Trousinski? How's he feeling about the whole affair?

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Don't you worry about Trousinski, Bob, he's not really dangerous. He just does his job the best way he knows how.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know what to tell you, I gota Job, you know. I start work tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I heard. What happened out there in the sticks, Bob? Where's Dianne?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know how whimsical women are. She finally found another dude to chase after, and down the road she went, chasing after him.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: You know what Bob, I've known you and Dianne since we were all kids and I find that a little hard to believe. Gentry rises from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: I'll see you around, Bob, and I sincerely hope you make out on that job you've got and straighten up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Bob listens to a radio song. Smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CITY NIGHT
dialogues.text: The cloudy sky lights up from an electrical storm, and thunder booms out slightly after. ‘

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: A car pulls up to the curb and a shadowy figure gets out and enters the Hotel. INT. BOB'S ROOM NIGHT ak A knock comes on the door. Bob is laying in bed playing solitaire. He gets up and answers the knock. A sad old COUNTRY AND WESTERN tune is playing on a little radio by Bob's bed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's me, Dianne. Bob throws the door open and smiles. Dianne steps in hesitantly and looks around at the room's dismal appearance. She looks shocked.  9-10-88 89

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Jesus, what kind of dump is this? And where's the female? You might as well trot her out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You don't ever change, do you, Dianne?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: You goddamn right I don't. Why should 1?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I was just remarking on how good you look. I didn't mean nothing by it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I'll bet. You're slipperier than an eel, Bob, no one ever catches you off balance because you stay off balance constantly, just to stay on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is that all you got to say? Is that why you come up here, or did you just want to see me down and out?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to see you period. How's that methadone thing?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, so-so. I got a job, bet you never expected to see that.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: No shit, where're you working?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, down at some machine shop on Western.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What do you do there?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Drill holes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Drill holes?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know, like the holes that bolts fit into and such.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? How do you like it?  9-10-88 90

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, to tell you the truth, it's kind of a drag.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Then you're really serious. You're going to go on with this thing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, I am, Dianne. Sit down here, why don't you take off your coat and stay awhile.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, I can't Bob, I got people waiting for me down in the car. I just came up to see how you was doing. Here... Dianne struggles with something in her purse, and comes up with a small package. Bob smiles

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: This is from Rick and the rest of us. We kind of thought you might need a taste once in awhile. and takes the package.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dianne. I sure do appreciate you all thinking of me.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: What happened? What made you turn around that day? Was it me, did I do something wrong? Or was it just that thing with Nadine?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, baby, it wasn't you. It was Nadine's death and the hex that she threw on us with the hat. And then I panicked when I looked out into that parking lot and seen all those cop cars. I just knew I was dead. Everything up to then had gone wrong and so I started coping deuces. I prayed like never before. I said “God, Devil, Sun, whoever you are up there that controls this whirly-girly mad tumbling world, please have pity on me. Please let me get this poor girl's body out of  yroLu-bo 91

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (continued) this motel room and into the ground so I don't have to spend the rest of my life in prison. And God, Sun, Satan, if you'll] do that for me, I'll show my appreciation by going back to the coast, getting on a methadone program, getting a job and living the good life." Well, I got out, and I promised, so here I am.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: Are you going to stick to it forever?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah. And, you know, for all the boredom the good life brings, it's not so bad. Even this crummy little room isn't so bad. I'ma regular guy. I got my regular job. And my regular room. Now I got my woman. . . Dianne sits down on the bed and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: You're crazy, Bob, you are really crazy. But I see what you mean. Jesus, Bob, if I had known what it was all about, I'd have come along with you, I thought you were mad at me for something.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Why don't you go tell your friends you're going to stay the night, and then come back up here and bed down with me for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I'd like to Bob, (Dianne lowers her eyes) but I got another old man now. I work for Rick now, ain't that a gas? There we were teaching the brat to steal, and now I'm on his crew. Things sure can get screwed around, can't they? Bob nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE
dialogues.text: I'd like to stay the night with you really I would. Only I'm Rick's old lady now. And you know me, Bob, I might have been a lot of things, but I never was a tramp. Bob manages a smile. A long pause.  200 201 202 203 204

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll see you, Dianne. (Bob leads Dianne out the door.) You stop back by sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob waves at Dianne as she walks down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It sure was good to see you. And you're really looking good. I sure wish I could go with you and win you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob slowly closes the door and wanders back to his bed and sits down slowly, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne's figure, in the rain, darkly stepping into the waiting car. Then the car takes off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob sitting.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S WORKPLACE DAY
dialogues.text: SNT. SUBS ae ee Bob drilling holes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DUSK
dialogues.text: Bob, carrying groceries and whistling, walks past a donut shop where Gentry is drinking a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks down the hall of his hotel and opens the door to his room. He is carrying the groceries.  206 207 208

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob enters his room, puts down the groceries and pokes around his closet, under a pile of rags in one corner, he comes up with the package Dianne had left him the night before and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Bob bounds up the stairs one flight. INT. HALLWAY DAY xe Bob knocks on Tom's door. Tom opens the door of his apartment. Bob hands his package to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: A little gift, someone left it for me last night, but I'm not going to need it, seein' as how I've got my new program going, so you take it. INT. ROOM DAY xk They both step into the room and Tom shuts and locks the door behind him. He lays the sock on the bedside table and empties the contents.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly what's in it, but...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: God Bless you my son. May you go to heaven. Let's see just what's in this. Oh, yeah - this is for squares, never touch the stuff. Now this here, this bottle of one hundred sixteenths of dilaudid, this could come in handy. This will certainly earn you an indulgence.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure. I've come a long, weird road since I knew you as a kid, Tom. I took everything you told me and took it further. Hitting the poisons when everybody else was cleaning up, getting on the program. I hada good run, but people got hurt. People were  209 210 9-10-88 94

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (continued) shot, busted, people died. I can't do it anymore. The girl I married still thinks she's Ma Barker but I'm thinking like Pa Kettle. My cross-roading days are done, I guess I hope to never see another sitting-duck Pharmacy. And I have to confess I don't know what it was all for.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (measuring his words) There are more things than our feet that carry us to sin, my son. Few things in my own past I'd just as soon forget. Who can say who gets a second chance? But I hope you make it, kid, may I fall down and be paralyzed if I don't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL NIGHT DUSK
dialogues.text: Bob leaves Tom's room and strides lightly down the stairs.-

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob opens the door and enters, opening up his closet to hang up his coat. The HAMMER OF A GUN CLICKS, and as Bob steps back, a man wearing a ski mask steps out of the closet with the gun aimed at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: MASK
dialogues.text: Where's it at, Bob, where's it at? CLOSE VIEW of Bob's head, there is a ROARING NOISE froma blow, and Bob is sent to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MASK
dialogues.text: We want your dope, man, where's the dope? Bob squirms on the floor as his mind races.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Man, I ain't got no dope. You think I'd be living in this flea trap 1£ I had any dope? Hell, I'm on the methadone program, and you guys come to me to rob for dope? Boy, that sure is a laugh.  9-10-88 95 Bob tries to make his point by letting out a laugh, but it doesn't work. The laugh doesn't come out right. It sounds more like a howl.

dialogues.speaker: MASK
dialogues.text: Okay, buster. You want it the hard way and we're just the dudes that can give it to you. Bob seems to recognize the voice.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is that your voice, David? David kicks him again in the head. Hands tie Bob's hands together.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: David, you little punk. I'm telling you the truth. I'm going straight. You ought to try it sometime. It's good for the soul.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fucking liar! Where is it, Bob? We heard you were here. We know this is all a scam you're Playing. The figures begin to kick Bob. And no matter how he moved he couldn't get away from their blows.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where is it, Bob, where is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Just like on TV, fucking TV babies. What is the world coming to with all these TV babies. What are people going to do once they snap that they have raised a whole new breed of little monsters? FINALLY THE ATTACKERS are out of breath, breathing hard through their ski masks.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Hell, I should have stayed on the road, I was stupid to think that cleaning up my hand would make any difference to the hat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So where is it?!

dialogues.speaker: ACCOMPLICE
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? The bastard either doesn't have it or he's going to die before he tells us.  211 212 213 214 9-10-88 96

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Kill the sonofabitch. 1'11 bet you the next bastard we capture will tell us where it's at. So he's tough. They ain't all tough. I say kill him. Did you hear me Bob? No response. David raises the pistol (a twenty-two) and shoots Bob once in the back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEXT DOOR ARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: An older WOMAN has her ear to the wall, when she hears the shots, she coils back. She listens some more and hears the TWO leave.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: The old woman sees that the hallway is clear. She races to Bob's room; sees Bob on the ground, getting up. She goes to the end of the hall and calls on a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. /EXT. HOTEL NIGHT
dialogues.text: Detective Gentry arrives outside the Hotel just as they are bringing Bob out on a stretcher. One look at Bob convinces Gentry that Bob is hurt badly. No, Bob doesn't look good at all.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: How's he doing? An ATTENDANT shrugs. VIEW of Tom the Priest looking out his window. Ambulance goes down the road.

dialogues.speaker: NT BULANCE GHT
dialogues.text: Gentry squats next to the stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: You awake, Bob? Gentry hangs over Bob.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Who got you, Bob? Bob opens his eyes and smiles.  9-10-88 97

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Was it Halamer? Bob shakes his head from side to side meaning no, the lights from streetlights play with his face. Gentry wipes his brow, glad that Halamer wasn't responsible.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Who got you? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The hat. Gentry leans closer.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: The hat, Bob? Did you say the hat? Gentry reaches into a pocket and takes out a little black book to write in. Bob nods yes. Gentry writes it down.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Tell Dianne to watch out for the hat. Tell her.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Okay, Bob, tell Dianne to watch out for the hat. Again Bob nods.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: Did the hat shoot you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No, the TV baby shot me.

dialogues.speaker: GENTRY
dialogues.text: The TV baby shot you, Bob, but the hat sent them, is that it? Bob laughs at Gentry

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Never mind. I'11 tell her myself. Gentry is a bit confused, but writes it down in the black book. Close VIEW of Bob's face, his smile, and the VIEW tilts up to see out the ambulance window.
